title: Foundations26
text:
Programme Structure
Week 1 (w/c 29th September 2025) ‚Äì Introductory Week Workshops
Workshop 1: Academic Skills and University Transition (2 hours)
Workshop 2: Essay Writing Fundamentals + Formative Essay (2 hours)
Workshop 3: Planning and Researching a Specific Essay (2 hours)
Workshop 4: Library Skills and Information Literacy (2 hours)
Workshop 5: Digital Skills for Psychology Students (2 hours)
Digital Workbook: APA Format, Referencing, Plagiarism, and AI Use



And a ‚ÄòGetting to know each other psychologically‚Äô social!

title: Foundations26
text:
Personal Tutors
Personal Tutor Assignment
Each student will be assigned a Personal Tutor

First 1-to-1 meeting next week
Group meetings fortnightly in terms 1 & 2
Scheduled on your Timetables eventually!

title: Foundations26
text:
Assessment Overview
Coursework

10 summative assignments
1 formative (practice) essay

Examinations

3 timed in-person exams (Term 3)
Exception: PS50008A has MCQ test instead
2hr in person exams
6 questions given, 3 from each ‚Äòhalf‚Äô of the module (sections a & b)
You answer 1 question from each section (2 in total)

Weighting by Module:

PS50005B, PS50006B, PS50007B: 50% coursework + 50% exams
PS50008A: 80% coursework + 20% in-class MCQ test

title: Foundations26
text:
Detailed Assessment Breakdown
PS50005B: Social & Developmental Psychology
1 social essay + 1 developmental essay + 1 combined exam
PS50006B: Psychology & Life
1 personality essay + 1 applications essay + 1 combined exam
PS50007B: Psychobiology & Cognitive Psychology
1 psychobiology essay + 1 cognitive essay + 1 combined exam
PS50008A: Research Methods and Experimental Design
1 research plan + 1 EDS assignment + 1 MCQ test + 1 research report (double weighted)

title: Foundations26
text:
Generative AI Policy


Strict AI Usage Rules
You must NOT use generative AI to generate any work for assessment

Includes ALL formats: text, images, video, sound, animation
Any exceptions will be clearly stated on module VLE pages
AI-generated work = Academic Misconduct
May result in formal investigation
When in doubt, don‚Äôt use it!

title: Foundations26
text:
Progression Requirements
Pass Mark: 50%
Required for all assessments and modules
Progression to Year 1: 60%+

Pass all four modules (50%+ each)
Achieve 60%+ overall average

Resit Policy
If you fail a module, you get two further attempts:

Attempt 1: Late summer
Attempt 2: Following academic year

title: Foundations26
text:
Extenuating Circumstances
When to Apply for ECs
Missing deadlines or exams requires EC application + supporting statement
Timing Rules:

Unforeseen events: Apply within 7 days of missed deadline
Foreseen events: Apply 14 working days before deadline

How to Apply:

Via your MyGoldsmiths account
Full details on main programme page

title: Foundations26
text:
Marking and Feedback
Coursework

Submit via learn.gold module pages
Marks & feedback: 3 weeks after submission
Due dates posted on main programme page

Examinations

EDS MCQ: 3 weeks + in-class feedback
Final exams: Results via MyGoldsmiths (July)

title: Foundations26
text:
Timetable Information
Teaching Days
Wednesday, Thursday & Friday in term 1
Teaching Hours

Term 1: 10am - 3:30pm
Term 2: 10am - 4pm (TBC)

Check Your Timetable
www.gold.ac.uk/students/timetable/

title: Foundations26
text:
Attendance Policy
ALL Classes are COMPULSORY

Lectures, seminars, labs, personal tutor sessions
SEAts Monitoring System

Download the SEAts App
Register attendance at start of every class
Non-attendance alerts may lead to Academic Probation

More info: gold.ac.uk/students/seats/

title: Foundations26
text:
Lecture Recordings


Recording Policy
This is an in-person degree, not online!

Recordings are not made for any sessions
Must attend in-person for full learning experience
To record yourself: notify lecturer first

Plan to attend all sessions!






Tip


It‚Äôs easier to keep up than catch up!

title: Foundations26
section: I‚Äôm in no rush to go anywhere, so can stay and answer any questions!
text:
I‚Äôm in no rush to go anywhere, so can stay and answer any questions!
Closing words - We are excited about the year ahead, and our shared mission is‚Ä¶
Seeing you in Year 1 this time next year!

title: Integrated Degree BSc (Hons) Psychology
text:
Goldsmiths, University of London



Foundation Certificate in Psychology

Progression to BSc (Hons) Psychology




Not applicable




1 year full-time (Foundation Certificate)

3 years full-time (undergraduate degree)




This is a four-year degree at Goldsmiths. If students successfully achieve the progression requirements of the foundation year, they can continue with the full-time three-year BSc (Hons) Psychology.
The programme is ideal for anyone interested in psychology and its applications who wants to boost their academic profile and progress to the BSc Psychology. It focuses on introductory psychology and its theoretical and research approaches (developmental, social, cognitive, psychobiology, research methods). A study skills module develops academic writing and research skills.
Students may access specialist and general-purpose research laboratories, including EEG, infant lab, and visual perception labs.




Normally 18 years of age by 30th September of entry year

No formal qualifications required, but must demonstrate potential to benefit from programme

Grade B GCSE English (or equivalent) required

Grade C GCSE or equivalent in Mathematics advantageous

Selection normally by interview





Introduce the scope and complexity of Psychology

Provide knowledge of theoretical approaches

Develop skills for further study in Psychology

Provide supportive learning environment

Encourage lifelong independent learning








A1 Fundamental approaches and fields of Psychology

A2 Methods, concepts, terminology

A3 Skills for independent study

A4 Statistical methodology and research methods





B1 Synthesise academic material and develop arguments

B2 Analyse critical ideas

B3 Illustrate points of view

B4 Critically evaluate concepts and continue research





C1 Apply statistics and experimental design to Psychology





D1 Research and information retrieval

D2 Structured and coherent presentation of ideas

D3 Potential for new skill development

D4 Skills necessary for undergraduate study






Direct teaching with preparatory tasks

Lectures, discussions, group work, guest speakers

Additional readings and handouts

Critical engagement with theories and studies

Support in numeracy and presentation skills






Essays

Unseen examinations

Research reports

Multiple choice tests






80-100% Outstanding/Exceptional: Original argument, detailed accuracy

70-79% Very Good: Broad understanding, critical evaluation, well-structured

60-69% Good: Competent, extensive reading, clear evidence

50-59% Pass: Satisfactory, descriptive, lacks depth

31-49% Fail: Limited, confused, poor structure

16-30% Bad fail: Weak, minimal relevance

1-15% Very bad fail: No structure or relevance

0%: Non-submission or plagiarism





All students take the following compulsory modules:

Personal Tutor: assigned to all students, meeting fortnightly

Access to Library, VLE, handbooks, handouts

Feedback on all assessed work

Disability and Wellbeing Services support

Academic Skills Centre workshops and one-to-one provision






Progression to Year 1 of BSc Psychology

Graduates work in a variety of fields, often as assistants, therapists, or in postgraduate study

Annual Psychology Careers Talks

3D Graduate scheme to support reflective, self-managing learners

No formal placements, but internal/external opportunities advertised






Foundation year: 120 credits at Level 3

Progression requires passing all modules (50%+) and achieving average of 60%+

Possible progression at 58% with mitigation






Students passing foundation year eligible for Foundation Certificate award

Marks from foundation year do not count toward final classification

title: Integrated Degree BSc (Hons) Psychology
text:
Foundation Certificate in Psychology

Progression to BSc (Hons) Psychology

title: Integrated Degree BSc (Hons) Psychology
text: Not applicable

title: Integrated Degree BSc (Hons) Psychology
text:
1 year full-time (Foundation Certificate)

3 years full-time (undergraduate degree)

title: Integrated Degree BSc (Hons) Psychology
text:
This is a four-year degree at Goldsmiths. If students successfully achieve the progression requirements of the foundation year, they can continue with the full-time three-year BSc (Hons) Psychology.
The programme is ideal for anyone interested in psychology and its applications who wants to boost their academic profile and progress to the BSc Psychology. It focuses on introductory psychology and its theoretical and research approaches (developmental, social, cognitive, psychobiology, research methods). A study skills module develops academic writing and research skills.
Students may access specialist and general-purpose research laboratories, including EEG, infant lab, and visual perception labs.

title: Integrated Degree BSc (Hons) Psychology
text:
Normally 18 years of age by 30th September of entry year

No formal qualifications required, but must demonstrate potential to benefit from programme

Grade B GCSE English (or equivalent) required

Grade C GCSE or equivalent in Mathematics advantageous

Selection normally by interview

title: Integrated Degree BSc (Hons) Psychology

Develop skills for further study in Psychology

Provide supportive learning environment

Encourage lifelong independent learning

text:

title: Integrated Degree BSc (Hons) Psychology
text: C1 Apply statistics and experimental design to Psychology

Multiple choice tests

title: Integrated Degree BSc (Hons) Psychology
text:
80-100% Outstanding/Exceptional: Original argument, detailed accuracy

70-79% Very Good: Broad understanding, critical evaluation, well-structured

60-69% Good: Competent, extensive reading, clear evidence

50-59% Pass: Satisfactory, descriptive, lacks depth

31-49% Fail: Limited, confused, poor structure

16-30% Bad fail: Weak, minimal relevance

1-15% Very bad fail: No structure or relevance

0%: Non-submission or plagiarism
